prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO in the COSMOS wall at z~0.12
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal aims to detect redshifted CO (1-0) coincident with HI-detected galaxies in the COSMOS wall at z~0.12.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim to resolve the CO line into at least ten channels (assuming a width of 100 km/s, which is 2/3 of the assumption for the HI profiles), and we will likely smooth the CO line from its native resolution of 2.86 km/s. The other three windows will be used for continuum at 90-100 GHz.

With 2" resolution, we will detect the central 5 kpc of the molecular disk with the highest signal to noise in the least amount of integration time. If the disk is larger than 5 kpc, we will resolve it into more than one beam. The largest angular scale is not likely to be more than 10-15 kpc (or ~5"), so our needs are well met by a single 12m configuration.

From the stacked spectra of the HI non-detections, an average HI mass of 1.8e9 Msun is calculated in the COSMOS field at the redshift of the wall (z~0.12). We aim to detect 10% of this mass in H2 over the central 5 kpc of each galaxy. Assuming a Galactic conversion factor, we require a sensitivity of 200 mK (7 mJy in a 2" beam), or an RMS of 40 mK for a 5sigma detection. We assume line widths of 100 km/s and want to resolve the line into ten channels, so these sensitivities use a bandwidth of 10 km/s.
For the continuum, we perform SED fits to existing Herschel data where it is available and extrapolate the fits to 100 GHz. In some cases, the extrapolation indicates that we will not detect the continuum with our achievable RMS of 29 uJy, but we can use these predictions to test whether excesses exist (as have been predicted in the presence of radio quiet AGN). Our 29 uJy sensitivity corresponds to a detection limit of 10^8 solar masses of cold dust, assuming T=25 K and beta=2.0.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Mapping the content and evolution of both the atomic and molecular gas in galaxies beyond the local Universe is key to understanding how gas is acquired and consumed. Until recently, HI obsevations have been limited to the local volume, but CHILES, an ongoing HI deep field survey at the VLA, will enable us to directly detect cold gas in galaxies out to an unprecedented redshift of z=0.5. We propose to use ALMA to help us to explore this new redshift regime: we will trace the cosmic web in cold gas (atomic + molecular hydrogen) for the first time by targeting galaxies detected in HI in the wall at z=0.12 in the COSMOS field. In only 5.1 hours of ALMA time, we can detect CO (1-0) in 16 HI-detected galaxies and ascertain the full cold gas budget via direct emission line mapping in this cosmic structure.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
